headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2011 Apartment Investment & Management Company Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note that today's event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference call over to y
componenttext: Good afternoon and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2011 Apartment Investment & Management Company Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note that today's event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference call over to your presenter, Ms. Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Ms. Cohn, please go ahead.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jamie. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we may make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to the 2012 results. These statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties,
componenttext:
Thank you, Jamie. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we may make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to the 2012 results. These statements are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. Also we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures such as funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on Aimco's website. 
The participants for our today's call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, who will provide opening remarks; Keith Kimmel, Executive Vice President in charge of Property Operations; Ernie Freedman, our CFO, who will review 2011 results and 2012 guidance. Also in the room today are John Bezzant, Executive Vice President, Transaction; Miles Cortez, EVP and Chief Administrative Officer; and Dan Matula, Executive Vice President of Redevelopment and Construction Services. We are all available to answer questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. I will turn the call over to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on the call for your interest in Aimco. I'd like to take a few minutes and the beginning just to talk about the big picture. The Apartment business was good last year and I think will be as good or better this y
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on the call for your interest in Aimco. I'd like to take a few minutes and the beginning just to talk about the big picture. 
The Apartment business was good last year and I think will be as good or better this year. Demographics remain strongly positive and the economy seems to be slowly recovered. And I'm pretty sure that 2012 will be a very solid year for Aimco. About 1/2 of our expected rent growth is already in the bank from leases  made last year and so far this year just waiting to earn in. Our Renewal business remains quite steady with more than 1/2 of our customers renewing their leases at rents up 5% or more. 
In most markets, we enjoyed steady consumer demand for new leases, which is up average daily occupancy and producing higher rents. 
Our portfolio is good and getting better. It is more and more concentrated than the most desirable markets with higher rents and greater expected rent growth. Last year, average rents were up 9% to more than $1,140. This year, we expect average rents to be up another $120 or 10%, more than $1,260. About 1/2 of that increase in average rents will come from rent growth and about 1/2 will come from the sale of properties with lower rent. 
We imply the same selling discipline to our Affordable portfolio where we plan to sell 60 Affordable properties this year, reducing our allocation to the Affordable business to less than 10% of net asset value. 
On the buy side, we expect to make at least $200 million of property acquisitions, primarily by buying out limited partners in 11 partnerships that own 19 properties. We've already closed on 4 of these transactions and we expect to close the 3 more this month. 
We like partnerships acquisitions because we already operate in real estate and know it well. Partnership acquisition are especially accretive where we can eliminate overhead costs. For example, all 7 of the transactions that we closed in January or expect to close in February are public partnerships, all the cost of SEC reporting, required audits, Sarbanes-Oxley compliance and so on and that's a lot of cost to eliminate. So that's it. 
After this year we'll be largely done with a decade of partnership acquisitions and we will enjoy a simpler, more transparent lower-cost business. So we are actively pursuing other acquisition opportunities especially where we see that our operating and redevelopment skills can add value and enhance returns. 
Even as we upgrade our portfolio by selling weaker properties, we are also having higher rent, better located properties to redevelopment. Over the next few years, redevelopment will be an important contributor to improve portfolio quality and the faster rent growth. We expect to have 8 redevelopments underway this year. 4 in coastal California and 4 others in Seattle, Chicago and Philadelphia. We expect to spend more than $400 million in these properties over the next 2 years or so with current returns on untrended rents greater than 7% and unlevered internal rates of return greater than 10%. 
Three, Treetops, which is now known as Pacific Bay business, Lincoln Place and Madera Vista are currently vacant to the return to service with more than 1,200 units with target rents over $2,400, will upgrade our portfolio and these especially accretive. The findings, we have a big pipeline of redevelopment opportunities for 2 or 3 years. 
We remain focused on simplifying our business and reducing costs. As I mentioned earlier, closing out 11 more property partnerships will save legal accounting and other overhead costs. We've also agreed to sell, a legacy asset management business and management buyout. 
While the final closing will be later this year after conditions are satisfied and regulatory approvals are received, overhead savings are already being realized. So once more, Aimco upside costs will be down year-over-year and this year by another 12% or $12 million. 
Aimco balance sheet is liquid and save. Our business is self funding with ample liquidity including a new $500 million unused revolving line of credit with an extended term and reduced prices. We have limited near-term refunding obligations, largely fixed interest rates and essentially no debt with recourse to income. 
This property income increasing, retained earnings supplies to amortized property debt and opportunistic redemption of a high-cost preferred stock, we expect balance sheet leverage to come down over the next few years. For example, we expect the ratio on EBITDA-to-interest to be about 2.5:1 by the fourth quarter of this year. We expect the ratio of debt-to-EBITDA to be less than 7.5:1 by year end. 
In sum, we have a favorable environment, a clear plan and a veteran team that works well together. We expect 2012 to be a year of steady progress across all metrics. With this in mind, the Aimco Board of Directors reasserted to increase the stock dividend by 50% to the annual rate of $0.72 per share. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Keith Kimmel, Head of Aimco Property Operation. Keith and his team are doing a great job and I thank them for their hard work. Keith?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. We had a very solid year in 2011. I'm exceptionally proud of the accomplishments of the team that I'm fortunate to lead. During 2011, we successfully increased rents and saw improvement year-over-year each quarter. We stayed disciplined of
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. We had a very solid year in 2011. I'm exceptionally proud of the accomplishments of the team that I'm fortunate to lead. During 2011, we successfully increased rents and saw improvement year-over-year each quarter. We stayed disciplined of our costs and actually reduced expenses both on and offsite year-over-year. We upgraded our technology, implemented a new property operating system and redesigned the Aimco website, thereby, enhancing the customer experience. And we retained a high percentage of our residents base by the prioritization of customer service and customer satisfaction. 
We finished 2011 on a positive note with Conventional Same Store fourth quarter NOI up 5.3% over the third quarter and up 5.8% year-over-year. This increase was driven by revenues being up 0.8% over the third quarter and up 3.3% year-over-year, while expenses were down 0.6% compared to the third quarter and down 1% year-over-year. 
Now for some additional context around the fourth quarter revenue numbers. Fourth quarter renewal rents were up 5.2% and new lease rents were up 0.7% for a blended increase of 3%. In our target markets, which represent about 86% of our NOI, occupancy was stable and new lease rents were up 1.6%. 
In our non-target markets, we focused on gaining occupancy and getting to a strong jump up to 2012. After some softening early in the fourth quarter, demand strengthened. And we finished 2011 with high occupancy across the portfolio. 
Average daily occupancy increased each week during the November and December to the year end of 95.7%. For the full year 2011, Conventional Affordable Same Store NOI was up 5.9% driven by revenues being up 2.9% and expenses being down 1.8%. 
Now for 2012. We began the year in good shape, thanks to solid 2011 leasing activity, which will contribute 2.1% to the 2012 revenue growth, substantially better than the 0.4% we started with in 2011. 
January is on track, finishing according to plan. We remain highly focused on cost control. The expected increase year-over-year in expenses is entirely due to higher property taxes and property insurance costs. Utility expense increases are reimbursed by our customers. And in aggregate, all expenses will be flat or down year-over-year driven by operational efficiencies. 
Finally, I'd like to take a moment to recognize the stellar work of my colleagues, particularly, Karen Erasco and Kevin Rozier, the area Vice Presidents of the east and west property operations. Proud to be part of a team so wholeheartedly dedicated to Aimco's vision. With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Ernie Freedman, our Chief Financial Officer. Ernie?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. I'll provide some additional highlights from 2011 and discuss 2012 guidance. We provided 2011 highlights from operation so I'll focus on our portfolio, redevelopment, balance sheet and financial results. John Bezzant and the transactio
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. I'll provide some additional highlights from 2011 and discuss 2012 guidance. We provided 2011 highlights from operation so I'll focus on our portfolio, redevelopment, balance sheet and financial results. 
John Bezzant and the transactions team sold 151 properties in 2011. They sold 25 low-rate Conventional properties. These properties have average rents of $649 compared to our current portfolio today of $1,143. We also sold 45 Affordable properties for an average ownership was 39% and we continue to reduce the size of our third-party asset management activities to the sale of 81, properties. Properties we retain have higher rents and higher expected rent and NOI growth. Importantly, capital replacement or CR spending is a smaller percentage of their revenue and in the case for lower rent properties. 
As a result of the 2011 property sales, we expect free cash flow margin and AFFO to grow faster than NOI margin and FFO. 
Turning to redevelopment. Dan Matula and the team broke ground on our Pacific Bay redevelopment, starting the first phase of our Lincoln Place redevelopment and established a pipeline of projects lined up for starts in 2012 and 2013. Just 3 of these properties are presently baked in, we do not expect the redevelopment activity to be near-term dilutive to FFO and AFFO. We do expect it to be accretive in 2013 and beyond. 
Regarding the balance sheet. Our coverage has improved during 2011 due to earnings growth and a net reduction in debt. EBITDA coverage of interest increased to 2 18:1 to 2 07:1. EBITDA coverage of interest and preferred dividends also increased to 1 78:1 to 1 68:1. A detailed and supplemental schedule for our earnings release, we reduced total leverage, which includes preferred stock by $84 million. 
Adding fuel in our team, we refinanced over $6 million of property debt maturing in the years 2011 through 2015 at rates averaging 4.9%. These loans mature on average in 9 years. There are properties that is held back by 46 insurance companies, pension funds, banks and other institution in addition to the GSEs. 
We also increased our revolving credit facility expanding the number of participants, ending the maturity dates to December 2016, inclusive of extension options and reducing its costs. In addition to lowering our total amount of preferred equity, we also issued a new class of preferred equity with a total coupon of 7%. Both of these from initial offering were used to redeem higher cost of preferred equity. 
The efforts of Keith, John, Dan, Patti and the entire Aimco team led FFO up 11% year-over-year from 2010 and AFFO up by 5%. 
Turning to 2012, you'll find on Page 5 of our earnings release our detailed guidance for the full year of 2012 as well as guidance for the first quarter. There's a lot of information there so rather than reading the schedule to everyone, I'll just point out a few key items. 
Projected full year FFO is $1.70 to  $1.82 per share. At the midpoint, this is an increase of about 8% from our 2011 AFFO, $1.64. AFFO is anticipated to be up about 21% from 2011. FFO growth is driven primarily by expected revenue growth and lower offsite costs. AFFO was up more due to delevering effect of lower rent assets that required similar amounts of capital replacement spending at the current portfolio. 
Our assumptions around operating results are as follows. Full year NOI growth for our Conventional Same Store portfolio is expected to be between 5.25% and 7.25% with revenue growth of 4.5% and 5.5% and expense growth of 2.5% to 3%. Keith pointed out the expense increases are due almost entirely to the anticipated increases in property taxes and property insurance. 
While utility and costs are also expected to increase, these increases will be offset by reimbursements from our customers. All other expense line items in the aggregate are expected to be flat or down. 
Regarding our balance sheet, we entered 2012 with $173 million of property debt maturities in the next 12 months. This rate loss of $55 million of that amount leaving us $118 million or about 2.5% of our total property debt remaining to refinance. 
Property debt amortization in 2012 will be $83 million or a little less than 2% of our property debt. We now said in our earnings news release that we entered into an agreement to transfer Asset Management of our, portfolio effective February 6  and to sell the minority interest of the portfolio to the new asset manager upon satisfaction of certain conditions and regulatory approvals. We expect the sale to close later in the second half of 2012. 
With this sale, we will liquidate all of our legacy Asset Management business. In 2011, we generated less than $0.01 of FFO from our, relationship. And is anticipated that for 2012, we'll generate a similar amount of FFO. 
On Page 4 of the earnings release, we discussed how we expect coverages to further improve from 2012 from our growth of operations and balance sheet activities. 
Annualizing  our anticipated EBITDA in the fourth quarter of 2012, we expect EBITDA coverage of interest expense to be approximately 2.5:1. EBITDA coverage of interest expense and preferred dividends to be approximately 2:1. Debt to EBITDA of approximately 7.5x and debt and preferred equity EBITDA of approximately 9x. 
I'm happy to report that we're off to good start in all of these areas and we are looking forward to a successful year ahead. With that, we will now open up the call for questions. 
Please limit your questions to 2 per time in the queue. Jamie, I'll turn it over to you for the first question, please?

componenttext: I'm just trying to understand the first quarter guidance a bit more. $0.35 implies a pretty big drop from the fourth quarter. So just wondering how you get from the fourth quarter down to $0.35 and then how that rings back up through the year to get you do the $1.77?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure, Eric. Let me walk you through the details on that. In our guidance, we provided sequential NOI growth from our Conventional Same Store play to be about the midpoint of about 3%. And that's mainly due to the expenses. We do expect revenues to be up a
componenttext: Sure, Eric. Let me walk you through the details on that. In our guidance, we provided sequential NOI growth from our Conventional Same Store play to be about the midpoint of about 3%. And that's mainly due to the expenses. We do expect revenues to be up about $0.01 but we expect expenses to offset unfortunately be down about $0.04. And that's just part of that is seasonal as we go from the fourth quarter to  first quarter in terms of the utility cost. And part of that is we had just a very good expense quarter in the fourth quarter. Secondly, Eric, we had about $2 million in the fourth quarter of 2011 of nonrecurring income. And we're not projecting nonrecurring income in the first quarter. That's not the $0.02 going down for us. That gets you from a $0.41 to about $0.36 and there's much other small things from us that's about $0.01 being down. So that's how we expect to end up at $0.35 at the midpoint with our first quarter 2012. Regarding what happens, Eric and for the rest of you, I don't want to get ahead of myself and quarter of the guidance going forward. But as you can see from what we're expecting from revenue growth and where we expect expense to be NOI for our whole portfolio, we do expect the operations to kick strong contribution in the year for us as we finish out 2012. And then you also know that in our guidance, we provided guidance for nonrecurring revenue of about $6 million, which is a little more back-end weighted in our numbers. And that's how we'll see our FFO contribution ramp up in the second, third and fourth quarter.

componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. And then the thing about this $0.13 of dilution that you provided, I think from the property sales in 2011, 2012, how much of that is just from the sale of the asset managed portfolio? And I know you said you didn't want to say when the sale was going to occur. But I'm trying to figure out how dilutive that transaction in particular is going to be and so we can carry that forward into the coming years.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. The Asset Management portfolio has virtually no impact in the dilution. In 2011, we earned about $0.01 or a little bit less than $0.01 from the activities from the, and it's the similar amount for 2012 as we are expecting that to be on our numbers f
componenttext: Sure. The Asset Management portfolio has virtually no impact in the dilution. In 2011, we earned about $0.01 or a little bit less than $0.01 from the activities from the, and it's the similar amount for 2012 as we are expecting that to be on our numbers for most of the year. So I don't want to talk about too much on what happens in the future. So with the fact that's it's only $0.01 in 2012 so it won't have a big difference. I think it's important to point out and you're right to point it out on our numbers that you see that there is a dilution from asset sales of $0.13. But offsetting that is the reduction in expenses across the organization of $0.09. So on state, it sounds like our sell activity is quite dilutive by the stable $1 million, as we simplify the company, we take other costs and we reduce our scale. And we really net those 2 numbers, you can see that even with all that tells me that it hasn't been that dilutive for us on an overall basis. And going forward we would expect something similar but the sale but we are contemplating in 2012. And the fact is that we contemplate those sales we have the opportunity to continue to save costs.

componenttextpreview: This is Ernie. What we're saying is we're actually different from the plans we've talked about when we provided a presentation publicly or on the NAREIT presentation for a few weeks approximately 2 months ago. What's happening there we're very focused on
componenttext: This is Ernie. What we're saying is we're actually different from the plans we've talked about when we provided a presentation publicly or on the NAREIT presentation for a few weeks approximately 2 months ago. What's happening there we're very focused on getting our coverages more in line with where our peers are and we want to provide guide for those folks where that is coming in. I'll point out the numbers that I mentioned that both in the release and my script, we're annualizing the fourth quarter numbers. And we did talk to folks before, we provided the annualized numbers, as well as the trailing 12 numbers and of course, with our growth that we're going to have and keep that throughout the year. On a trailing 12 basis, we don't get as far as when we do it with the annual numbers and that's where we'll be going forward. So it depends on the material plans and changes in terms of what we wanted to leverage. We want to make sure people understand that we're focused on that and we're committed to improve our coverages both through the cyclical recovery of NOI as well as bringing our overall debt balances down as well as the cost of that debt term.

componenttext: Just to follow up there on Terry with regards to tax credit, of course, when sell the legacy tax credit deal that we've done under the Aimco umbrella, I just want to -- I'm cautious to use the word business rather than financing opportunity. And as we talked about, we're selling some of our large Affordable assets and we think in the next couple of years we'll be down to just a handful other than our legacy tax rate deals. We may choose at some point in the future to use tax credit to finance redevelopment on some of those. In terms of trying to generate large syndication fees et cetera, that's not the goal of that. We're trying to accomplish what we're looking for cost effective financing to do redevelopment. And maybe 1 or 2 of those, we do a year. But to call it a business, would be a misnomer.

componenttext: Sure. We provided guidance, Rich, around what we've been doing redevelopment and property upgrades. On a recurring basis, we do expect to spend about $1,200 of capital per door, of which is about 900 and 950 of that is capital replacement. And the rest of that is capital improvements where we do get a little bit of revenue uplift. And that's been consistent for the last couple of years with times getting better and customers going to pay more rent. We have pushed for more property upgrades for the last couple of years and similar to last year, we'll be spending about $30 million to $40 million in addition to that approximate $1,200 a door.

componenttext: Okay. Just trying to understand better what's going on, on the new lease  side. When we look at the fourth quarter this year, you had 0.7%. That's actually below what you did in 4Q '10 on new leases although you were much stronger on renewals. And the 0.7 certainly suggests a drop off from the October that you talked about last quarter. So could you just talk about new lease pricing in general? Because your guidance at least the top end suggests that you had to get back to second or third quarter levels of increases from last year pretty quickly.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Dave, let me just say it this way. We sold for total revenue. And so while we're focused on new lease price, we're also focused on renewals and the blend of those 2. So that's how we're solving it.
componenttext: Dave, let me just say it this way. We sold for total revenue. And so while we're focused on new lease price, we're also focused on renewals and the blend of those 2. So that's how we're solving it.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: But can you talk a little bit more about the level of traffic or underlying drivers of weaker new lease pricing over the last few months as compared to October?
componenttext: But can you talk a little bit more about the level of traffic or underlying drivers of weaker new lease pricing over the last few months as compared to October?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Dave, this is Ernie. Keep in mind, we're not just solving for maximum new lease pricing or maximum renewal pricing. It's also the components with occupancy as well. And we grew occupancy more in the fourth quarter than we would have anticipated at the beg
componenttext: Dave, this is Ernie. Keep in mind, we're not just solving for maximum new lease pricing or maximum renewal pricing. It's also the components with occupancy as well. And we grew occupancy more in the fourth quarter than we would have anticipated at the beginning of the October call. We keep talking about really those kind of  the tale of the 2 portfolios for us in terms of where our target market portfolio and our on-target market portfolio. Keith have stressed that. And we did see the pricing is off a little bit more than non-target markets, which makes about 40% of our NOI than we grew occupancy significantly and put us in a strong position for starting in 2012. And our overall basis and I think similar to what other folks have been reporting for new lease rates and in the fourth quarter, our numbers on aggregate basis were about where those folks were. And in fact in our target portfolios, we're at the top end of that. That's carried over into January where things get modestly better but we haven't seen any spike from the new lease rates from where they are at today. But without providing guidance, Dave, to what's going to happen in the second, third and fourth quarters specifically around renewal and lease rates. And we do expect for the year that on a blended basis, we are being north of 5% on those. And as you can see from our numbers in the fourth quarter, we are already for renewals but there will be a lot of hard work to make sure we stay there for renewal. And we hope we can do even better. And as you saw in our numbers and during 2011, we had a pretty big spike in the new lease  rates as we got into the summer peak season and then trended down, which I think is very similar to almost everyone in the industry. I'm not within 2012 to look exactly like that but it will be surprising if they have, if similar to that.

componenttext: Dave, let me just kind of walk through our D.C.  Market. Revenues were up 5.1% from last year and as you may know, we have on average the B portfolio in Washington. headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Particularly with our disposition guidance, it gets us closer. We're going to get to eventually to a point where it's less than 10% of our NOI and NAV. And we're getting close to that but not quite there 2012. I expect there'd be, if we don't get it done
componenttext: Particularly with our disposition guidance, it gets us closer. We're going to get to eventually to a point where it's less than 10% of our NOI and NAV. And we're getting close to that but not quite there 2012. I expect there'd be, if we don't get it done in 2012, another maybe 20 or 25 more properties to sell as we go into 2013. So what I'll tell you is we're almost there. As we sell these properties, it doesn't make a big change in this contribution because these are Affordable, low ownership percentage across our portfolio. And then longer term, we continue to expect the quarter, we become smaller and smaller contributor to our overall income picture in terms of NAV as well as NOI. So when we would talk wanting to be about 10 or a little bit less and we're going to be almost there and we plan to do in 2012.

componenttext: Jana, this is Terry. I think we're roughly $10 billion as a comfortable size. We've been larger at other times. And it would be okay if we were a little bit larger, we've been smaller, that would be okay, too. Besides where transactions and improved performance can move the dial, and so I like our size, about where it is.

componenttext: Rich, 2 questions. We're getting closer to where that make sense for us. Keep in mind on prepared ATMs on cost of transactions, only 2% and unfortunately, the investment bankers look for more if we're going to do a bigger offerings And so the math isn't quite there. It's at higher expense but if there's anyone out there listening who'd like to offer us a lower amount. I'd be happy to take that phone call either now or as soon as we finish this call. So the math needs to be closer to 100 basis points for it to work on a larger offering, Rob, and for that to make sense to offset those transaction costs. We are very happy without ATMs performed as shares out there and it's a good trade for us to be able to issue about 7 20 or so yield and take out 8% for paper.

componenttext: Mike, this is Ernie. Let me address that. The return that Terry gave for all the redev projects that we're going to be doing, not just the 3 that and 2 of those have impairments associated with those, I can tell you we have not provided a specific project-by-project basis where those would be. I can tell you though that real estate values we're covering, the returns on an unimpaired values on those projects are only about 100, 200 basis points less than we are expecting based on the impaired values. But as we get further, we'll provide some guidance around specifically just in earnings release a few weeks ago, we get further along on Lincoln Place, which is the other major redevelopment project to have impairment a few years ago. We will provide that kind of information, too. I just want to be clear to folks that with the project returns are, we're going to be looking at both west.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Second one is the Treetops partner. Could you talk about, you gave the same store numbers for the Conventional portfolio, what's same store expectations for the Affordable portfolio in 2012? Also what is the number you are budgeting
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Second one is the Treetops partner. Could you talk about, you gave the same store numbers for the Conventional portfolio, what's same store expectations for the Affordable portfolio in 2012? Also what is the number you are budgeting for real estate tax increases in 2012? And what the impact of selling off the Asset Management business would have, if any, on the asset management fee income that you guys recognized?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: That's a clever way to go through that question. On portable Affordable, we expect Affordable to be up -- Affordable Same Store to be up from flat to 1%. It's mainly driven by a revenue increase but a little less than increase we saw in 2011 because we ha
componenttext: That's a clever way to go through that question. On portable Affordable, we expect Affordable to be up -- Affordable Same Store to be up from flat to 1%. It's mainly driven by a revenue increase but a little less than increase we saw in 2011 because we had some larger Affordable project that had the rent, the 5-year rent come up and we got a nice bump. We're not going to see that in 2012. And then on expenses behave similarly on the portfolio maybe a little bit more growth than we have in our Conventional portfolio. So Affordable will be up 0 to 1, the Affordable Same Store portfolio. Real estate tax is embedded in our guidance real estate taxes will increase between 5% and 6% and that's where the Conventional Same Store portfolio year-over-year. Within that number, Mike, 3.5% of the 5% to 6% is due to our expectation that both assessment and our tax rates are going to go up year-over-year. The other part then, the part that's the 3.5, so roughly the 1.5% to 2.5%, that increased due to the fact that we do expect we'll have less successful appeals on filing taxes in 2012 than we had in 2011. So again, real estate taxes embedded in our guidance, we're assuming to go up 5% to 6% on a comparable basis. Finally, with the Asset Management business. That's really going to contribute $0.01 to us overall in 2012. Basically, the revenues almost offset the expenses for that business. And then actually that business is something that's taxed and in our TRF as well. So the tax expense is associated with profits from that. So we basically expect that revenues we generate before taxes are offset more or less by expenses to run those assets. And then there's a minor tax expense associated with those to bring it down to less than a $0.01.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: So the impact would be then in the investment management wouldn't impact your Barbie management and it's not impacting G&A?

componenttext: Yes, that is both correct, Mike. We provided guidance around both for recurring revenues and nonrecurring revenues. So it's going to impact mainly the revenue number going forward and would come down a little bit because of that management fees go away. And then we lift out recurring expenses and nonrecurring expenses in our guidance for investment management. So you're exactly right today. All the impact is just in that area.

componenttext: I thought maybe it will be helpful to just get a snapshot of what Aimco will look like a year from now after you go through your dispositions. And so in listening to you of debt to EBITDA, 7.5x. Conventional business being 85% or thereabouts versus Affordable being 15%. 0 partnership business in the Conventional portfolio, pretty much. Is that about right? Do I have that reasonable snapshot of what things will look like?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: At close, Rich. Let's just go back over that because I think that's a useful way to look at it. it's the way I look at it is try to be very clear about where we're going. And so the first part about the Conventional business that I would flag is that we e
componenttext: At close, Rich. Let's just go back over that because I think that's a useful way to look at it. it's the way I look at it is try to be very clear about where we're going. And so the first part about the Conventional business that I would flag is that we expect the average rents at year end to be about $1,260 a month. Secondly, we expect that to be about 90%, about 90% of our net asset value. Third, we expect to have about 4% or 5% of our GAV. So make that maybe 10% of our NAV invested in redevelopment at untrended rents providing 7%, more than 7% current returns and unlevered IRRs greater than 10%. We expect almost no partnerships, almost no asset management. Offsite costs down by another 12% or $12 million. And debt to EBITDA, less than 7.5:1.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Eric Wolfe from Citi.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess I just want to follow up on Dave's question. You did 4.2% in weighted average rent growth in 2011, which, like you mentioned in your remarks, locks in about 50% of your revenue growth for 210 basis points. The 5% that you're predicting for this ye
componenttext: I guess I just want to follow up on Dave's question. You did 4.2% in weighted average rent growth in 2011, which, like you mentioned in your remarks, locks in about 50% of your revenue growth for 210 basis points. The 5% that you're predicting for this year. So just logically, right, you would have to be expecting 6% rent growth for this year for the math to work out a bit to that 5% revenue growth number, right? Or is there something -- is there a piece of am I missing?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: There's a couple of things there. The occupancy  guidance says we're going to come in relatively close to where we're at in 2012 but we'll see how that plays out. And in addition, about 10% of our income comes from other income, not from rents. It comes f
componenttext: There's a couple of things there. The occupancy  guidance says we're going to come in relatively close to where we're at in 2012 but we'll see how that plays out. And in addition, about 10% of our income comes from other income, not from rents. It comes from things we build to our customers, things like paper things like parking storage et cetera. And we've taken the opportunity to grow that at a pace quicker than we're growing rent. Now that said, it's only 10%. But that's also positive accretive to us. Otherwise, I would agree with your math. And when we're talking about we have seen north of 5% so that would coincide with the math that you said that you need to be closer to 6%. I'm not going to say exactly what number we're going to get to. And it could get as trade of occupancy and of the rate as we go through the year, we'll see how those circumstances will play itself out. But we're confident that come within the range of 4.5% to 5.5% when we laid that mark down. And knowing that you pointed out there that almost 1/2 of that is already baked in.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think Michael had a quick one as well. Ernie, just looking on Page 6 of the release and you have the FFO reconciliation. Can you just walk through -- you have this $0.13 and you title it '11 and '12 asset, and reinvestment. So I'm just wondering, can yo
componenttext: I think Michael had a quick one as well. Ernie, just looking on Page 6 of the release and you have the FFO reconciliation. Can you just walk through -- you have this $0.13 and you title it '11 and '12 asset, and reinvestment. So I'm just wondering, can you walk through how you came up with that $0.13? You obviously had growth dispositions last year of about $370 million, 40% of which happened in the fourth quarter. And it looks like you're targeting net of reinvestment about $330 million to $430 million of dispos this year, net of the acquisitions and the partnership interests. So I'm just trying to think about how you came up with that $0.13 of dilution. How much of it is effectively from '11 and how much of it is from '12 and how you've been through the math?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I don't have the details in front of me it's just it came from '11. This much came from '12, but you walked through exactly the logic associated with it, as well we're netting against the fact we know it's a small acquisition. We did we have a coupl
componenttext: Sure. I don't have the details in front of me it's just it came from '11. This much came from '12, but you walked through exactly the logic associated with it, as well we're netting against the fact we know it's a small acquisition. We did we have a couple of small acquisition in June of last year. We're getting to I think, income generating from that. So I'm happy to take it offline with you to provide you with some more details on how we get to the $0.13 but it's just the way to described. Sales from 2011, we had a big bunch of close in December so those are going to be quite dilutive to us because we have full year earnings of those in 2011. The sales in 2012 are assumed to be and as John talked about not by ratable but they will be spread out through the year. And based on our expectations for what we would sell of that from the cap rate, the math just worked out to be $0.13. But I just, unfortunately, I don't have it in front of me exactly how much is related to '11 and '12. But I'm happy to share that with you offline.

componenttext: Those are leverage pretty much on the rest of our portfolio. So on a property debt perspective, they're between 50%  and 55%, some will be a little higher. Some will be a little bit lower. And those are rates generally north of 5.5% because they are all loans so it's usually between 5.5% and 6%.

componenttext: There is definitely an earning because of the selling activity throughout the year but I don't know want to be too specific, Michael, as to what that could be because we're hopeful all things can happen in the business that could change our outlook on expenses with regards to acquisitions to do other things. So the answer is yes. There is some earnings in both from the fact of 2012 sales, we'll have some dilution into 2013. But our savings, not quite offset that. We'll come to close to offsetting them on a net FFO basis. Importantly, on AFFO basis, the offsets are completely because of levering effect of the capital spend.

componenttext: I wanted to ask about the Board's decision on the dividend. Looks like based on the midpoint of your AFFO guidance for this year, it's roughly 59% payout. And I know your plan is to use some of the retained to amortized debt. Do you think that 60% payout ratio is roughly where the Board wants to stay? And do you plan to continue that strategy? Or should we expect down the road to potentially there might be room for dividend increases greater than earnings growth because that payout ratio is still pretty low?

The decision making this year focused on adding a significant increase in the dividend, reflecting the prospects for the company. headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you very much. And in closing, I'd like to go back to Rich Anderson's question because I thought he framed it exactly right. So thank you, Rich, and focus on where we expect the company to be at the end of this year. We expect to have a good
componenttext: Great. Thank you very much. And in closing, I'd like to go back to Rich Anderson's question because I thought he framed it exactly right. So thank you, Rich, and focus on where we expect the company to be at the end of this year. We expect to have a good year with revenue up north of 5%, about 1/2 of that's in the bank. And our Renewal business is more than 1/2 of the remainder and those rents continue to grow at about 5% or more. We expect average rent to be about $1,260 a month by the end of the year. We expect the Affordable business to be less than 10% of our net asset value. We expect to close out our public partnerships and private partnerships on the conventional side, significantly reducing costs and increasing transparency. We expect to start 8 redevelopments as we just discussed with Andrew with 7% current returns unlevered IRRs north of 10% and untrended rents and have a deep pipeline of other opportunities besides, behind that. We accept offset costs year-over-year to be another 12% or $12 million. And we expect our balance sheet to end with debt to EBITDA of less than 7.5:1 at year end. So we've got a year of good progress ahead of us, a lot of work to do. And we thank you for your interest in the company.

componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2011 Apartment Investment & Management Company Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please also note that today's event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference call over to your presenter, Ms. Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President and General Counsel. Ms. Cohn, please go ahead.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jamie. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2012 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a descripti
componenttext:
Thank you, Jamie. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2012 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. Also we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures such as funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on Aimco's website. 
The participants on today's call will be Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO, who will provide opening remarks; Keith Kimmel, Executive Vice President, in charge of Property Operations; Ernie Freedman, our CFO, who'll review 2011 results and 2012 guidance. Also in the room today are John Bezzant, Executive Vice President, Transactions; Miles Cortez, EVP and Chief Administrative Officer; and Dan Matula, Executive Vice President of Redevelopment and Construction Services. We are all available to answer questions at the conclusion of our prepared remarks. 
I will now turn the call to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on the call for your interest in Aimco. I'd like to take a few minutes at the beginning just to talk about the big picture. The apartment business was good last year, and I think it will be as good or better thi
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and thanks to all of you on the call for your interest in Aimco. I'd like to take a few minutes at the beginning just to talk about the big picture. 
The apartment business was good last year, and I think it will be as good or better this year. Demographics remain strongly positive, and the economy seems to be slowly recovered. And I'm pretty sure that 2012 will be a very solid year for Aimco. About half of our expected rent growth is already in the bank from leases made last year and, so far, this year just waiting to earn in. Our renewal business remains quite steady, with more than half of our customers renewing their leases at rents up 5% and more. In most markets, we enjoyed steady consumer demand for new leases, pushing up average daily occupancy and producing higher rents.
Our portfolio is good and getting better. It is more and more concentrated than the most desirable markets, with higher rents and greater expected rent growth. Last year, average rents were up 9% to more than $1,140. This year, we expect average rents to be up another $120 or 10%, more than $1,260. About half of that increase in average rents will come from rent growth and about half will come from the sale of properties with lower rents. 
We apply the same selling discipline to our Affordable portfolio, where we plan to sell 60 Affordable properties this year, reducing our allocation to the Affordable business to less than 10% of net asset value. 
On the buy side, we expect to make at least $200 million of property acquisitions, primarily by buying out limited partners in 11 partnerships that own 19 properties. We've already closed on 4 of these transactions, and we expect to close 3 more this month. We like partnerships acquisitions because we already operate in the real estate and know it well. Partnership acquisitions are especially accretive, where we can eliminate overhead costs. For example, all 7 of the transactions that we closed in January or expect to close in February are public partnerships, with all the costs of SEC reporting, required audits, Sarbanes-Oxley compliance and so on, and that's a lot of costs to eliminate. So that's it. After this year, we'll be largely done with a decade of partnership acquisitions, and we will enjoy a simpler, more transparent, lower-cost business. So we're actively pursuing other acquisition opportunities, especially where we see that our operating and redevelopment skills can add value and enhance returns. 
Even as we upgrade our portfolio by selling weaker properties, we are also adding higher-rent, better-located properties to redevelopment. Over the next few years, redevelopment will be an important contributor to improve portfolio quality and to faster rent growth. We expect to have 8 redevelopments underway this year: 4 in coastal California and 4 others in Seattle, Chicago and Philadelphia. We expect to spend more than $400 million in these properties over the next 2 years or so with current returns on untrended rents greater than 7% and unlevered internal rates of return greater than 10%. 
Three: Treetops, which is now known as Pacific Bay Vistas, Lincoln Place and Madera Vista, are currently vacant due to the return to service of more than 1,200 units, with target rents over $2,400, will upgrade our portfolio and these especially accretive. Behind this, we have a deep pipeline of other good redevelopment opportunities for future here. 
We remain focused on simplifying our business and reducing costs. As I mentioned earlier, closing out 11 more property partnerships will save legal, accounting and other overhead costs. We've also agreed to sell the NAPICO, a legacy asset management business, in a management buyout. While the final closing will be later this year after conditions are satisfied and regulatory approvals are received, overhead savings are already being realized. So once more, Aimco upside costs will be down year-over-year this year by another 12% or $12 million. 
The Aimco balance sheet is liquid and save. Our business is self-funding with ample liquidity, including a new $500 million unused revolving line of credit with an extended term and reduced pricing. We have limited near-term refunding obligations, largely fixed interest rates and essentially no debt with recourse to income. 
With property income increasing, retained earnings supplies to amortized property debt and opportunistic redemption of high-cost preferred stocks, we expect balance sheet leverage to come down over the next few years. For example, we expect the ratio of EBITDA to interest to be about 2.5:1 by the fourth quarter of the year. We expect the ratio of debt to EBITDA to be less than 7.5:1 by year end. 
In sum, we have a favorable environment, a clear plan and a veteran team that works well together. We expect 2012 to be a year of steady progress across all metrics. With this in mind, the Aimco Board of Directors voted yesterday to increase the common stock dividend by 50% to the annual rate of $0.72 per share. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Keith Kimmel, Head of Aimco Property Operations. Keith and his team are doing a great job, and I thank them for their hard work. Keith?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. We had a very solid year in 2011. I'm exceptionally proud of the accomplishments of the team that I'm fortunate to lead. During 2011, we successfully increased rents and saw improvement year-over-year each quarter. We stayed disciplined of
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. We had a very solid year in 2011. I'm exceptionally proud of the accomplishments of the team that I'm fortunate to lead. During 2011, we successfully increased rents and saw improvement year-over-year each quarter. We stayed disciplined of our costs and actually reduced expenses both on and offsite year-over-year. We upgraded our technology, implemented a new property operating system and redesigned the Aimco website, thereby, enhancing the customer experience. And we retained a high percentage of our resident base by the prioritization of customer service and customer satisfaction. 
We finished 2011 on a positive note, with Conventional Same Store fourth quarter NOI up 5.3% over the third quarter and up 5.8% year-over-year. This increase was driven by revenues being up 0.8% over the third quarter and up 3.3% year-over-year, while expenses were down 6.6% compared to the third quarter and down 1% year-over-year. 
Now for some additional context around the fourth quarter revenue numbers. Fourth quarter renewal rents were up 5.2%, and new lease rents were up 0.7% for a blended increase of 3%. In our target markets, which represent about 86% of our NOI, occupancy was stable and new lease rents were up to 1.6%. 
In our non-target markets, we focused on gaining occupancy and getting to a strong jump-off point for 2012. After some softening in the -- early in the fourth quarter, demand strengthened. And we've finished 2011 with high occupancy across the portfolio. 
Average daily occupancy increased each week during the November and December to the year end of 95.7%. For the full year 2011, Conventional Affordable Same Store NOI was up 5.9% driven by revenues being up 2.9% and expenses being down 1.8%. 
Now for 2012. We began the new year in good shape, thanks to solid 2011 leasing activity, which will contribute 2.1% to the 2012 revenue growth, substantially better than the 0.4% we started with in 2011. January is on track, finishing according to plan. We remain highly focused on cost control. The expected increase year-over-year in expenses is entirely due to higher property taxes and property insurance costs. Utility expense increases are reimbursed by our customers. And in the aggregate, all expenses will be flat or down year-over-year, driven by operational efficiencies. 
Finally, I'd like to take a moment to recognize the stellar work of my colleagues, particularly, Karyn Marasco and Kevin Mosher, the Area Vice Presidents of the East and West Property Operations. Proud to be part of a team so wholeheartedly dedicated to Aimco's vision. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Ernie Freedman, our Chief Financial Officer. Ernie?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith. I'll provide some additional highlights from 2011 and discuss the 2012 guidance. Keith provided the 2011 highlights from operations, so I'll focus on our portfolio, redevelopments, balance sheet and financial results. John Bezzant and his
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith. I'll provide some additional highlights from 2011 and discuss the 2012 guidance. Keith provided the 2011 highlights from operations, so I'll focus on our portfolio, redevelopments, balance sheet and financial results. 
John Bezzant and his Transactions team sold 151 properties in 2011. We sold 25 low-rate Conventional properties. These properties had an -- had average rents of $649 compared to our current portfolio today of $1,143. We also sold 45 Affordable properties, where our average ownership was 39%, and we continue to reduce the size of our third-party asset management activities to the sale of 81 NAPICO properties. The properties we retained have higher rents and higher expected rent and NOI growth. Importantly, capital replacement or CR spending is a smaller percentage of their revenue, and it's the case for lower-rent properties. 
As a result of the 2011 property sales, we expect free cash flow margin and AFFO to grow faster than NOI margin and FFO. 
Turning to redevelopment. Dan Matula and the team broke ground on our Pacific Bay Vistas redevelopment, started the first phase of our Lincoln Place redevelopment and established a pipeline of projects lined up for starts in 2012 and 2013. Just 3 of these properties are presently baked in, we do not expect the redevelopment activity to be near-term dilutive to FFO and AFFO. We do expect it to be accretive in 2013 and beyond. 
Regarding the balance sheet. Our coverage has improved during 2011 due to earnings growth and a net reduction in debt. EBITDA coverage of interest increased to 2.18:1 from 2.07:1. EBITDA coverage of interest and preferred dividends also increased to 1.78:1 from 1.68:1. At detailed and supplemental schedule, 4 of our earnings release will reduce total leverage, which include preferred stock by $84 million. 
Patti Fielding in our team, we financed over $600 million of property debt maturing in the years 2011 through 2015 at rates averaging 4.9%. These loans mature on average in 9 years. Today, our property debt is helped by 46 insurance companies, pension funds, banks and other institutions in addition to the GSEs. Patti also increased our revolving credit facility, expanding the number of participants, ending the maturity dates to December 2016, inclusive of extension options and reducing its costs. In addition to lowering our total amount of preferred equity, we also issued a new class of preferred equity with a total equity coupon of 7%. Both these from the initial offering were used to redeem higher-cost preferred equity. 
The efforts of Keith, John, Dan, Patti and the entire Aimco team led the FFO up 11% year-over-year from 2010 and AFFO up by 5%. 
Turning to 2012, you'll find on Page 5 of our earnings release our detailed guidance for the full year 2012, as well as guidance for the first quarter. There's a lot of information there so rather than reading the schedule to everyone, I'll just point out a few key items. 
Projected full year FFO is $1.72 to $1.82 per share. At the midpoint, this is an increase of about 8% from our 2011 FFO of $1.64. AFFO is anticipated to be up about 21% from 2011. FFO growth is driven primarily by expected revenue growth and lower offsite costs. AFFO was up more due to the delevering effect of selling lower-rent assets that required similar amounts of capital replacement spending as the current portfolio. 
Our assumptions around operating results are as follows. Full year NOI growth for our Conventional Same Store portfolio is expected to be between 5.25% and 7.25%, with revenue growth of 4.5% to 5.5% and expense growth of 2.5% to 3%. Keith pointed out the expense increases are due almost entirely to anticipated increases in property taxes and property insurance. While utility and costs are also expected to increase, these increases will be offset by reimbursements from our customers. All other expense line items in the aggregate are expected to be flat or down. 
Regarding our balance sheet, we entered 2012 with $173 million of property debt maturities in the next 12 months, to give rate loss of $55 million of that amount, leaving us $118 million or about 2.5% of our total property debt remaining to refinance. 
Property debt amortization in 2012 will be $83 million or a little less than 2% of our property debt. We announced in our earnings release that we entered into an agreement to transfer asset management of our NAPICO portfolio effective February 6 and to sell our minority interest in the portfolio to the new asset manager upon satisfaction of certain conditions and regulatory approvals. We expect the sale to close later in the second half of 2012. With this sale, we will liquidate all of our legacy asset management business. In 2011, we generated less than $0.01 of FFO from our NAPICO relationships. And it's anticipated that for 2012, we'll generate a similar amount of FFO. 
On Page 4 of the earnings release, we discussed how we expect coverages to further improve during 2012 from our growth in operations and balance sheet activities. 
Annualizing our anticipated EBITDA in the fourth quarter 2012, we expect EBITDA coverage of interest expense to be approximately 2.5:1, EBITDA coverage of interest expense and preferred dividends to be approximately 2:1, debt to EBITDA of approximately 7.5x and debt and preferred equity EBITDA of approximately 9x. 
I'm happy to report that we are off to a good start in all of these areas, and we are looking forward to a successful year ahead. 
With that, we will now open up the call for questions. [Operator Instructions] Jamie, I'll turn it over to you for the first question, please.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to understand the first quarter guidance a bit more. $0.35 implies a pretty big drop from the fourth quarter, so just wondering how you get from the fourth quarter down to $0.35 and then how that rings back up through the year to get you t
componenttext: I'm just trying to understand the first quarter guidance a bit more. $0.35 implies a pretty big drop from the fourth quarter, so just wondering how you get from the fourth quarter down to $0.35 and then how that rings back up through the year to get you to the $1.77?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. Eric, this Ernie, and I'll walk you through the details on that. You'll note in our guidance we provided that we expect sequential NOI growth from our Conventional Same Store portfolio to be down at the midpoint about 3%. And that's mainly due to ex
componenttext: Sure. Eric, this Ernie, and I'll walk you through the details on that. You'll note in our guidance we provided that we expect sequential NOI growth from our Conventional Same Store portfolio to be down at the midpoint about 3%. And that's mainly due to expenses. We do expect revenues to be up about $0.01, but we expect expenses to offset -- unfortunately, be down about $0.04. And that's just -- part of that is seasonal, as we go from the fourth quarter to the first quarter, in terms of the utility costs. And part of that is it's been a very good expense quarter in the fourth quarter. Secondly, Eric, we had about $2 million in the fourth quarter of 2011 of nonrecurring income, and we're not projecting any nonrecurring income in the first quarter. That's another $0.02 going down for us. That gets you from our $0.41 to about $0.36, and there's much other small things that net out about $0.01 being down. So that's how we expect to end up at $0.35 at the midpoint for the first quarter 2012. Regarding what happens then, Eric, and for the rest of you, I don't want to get ahead of myself from providing quarterly guidance going forward, but as you can see from what we're expecting from revenue growth and where we expect expense to be in NOI for our whole portfolio, we do expect that operations can kick some strong contribution in the year for us as we finish out 2012. And then you also note in our guidance, we did provide guidance for nonrecurring revenues of about $6 million, which is a little bit more back-end weighted in our numbers, and that's how we see our FFO contribution ramp-up in the second, third and fourth quarter.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And then the thing about this $0.13 of dilution that you provided, I think from the property sales in 2011, 2012, how much of that is just from the sale of the Asset Management portfolio? And I know you said you didn't want to s
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And then the thing about this $0.13 of dilution that you provided, I think from the property sales in 2011, 2012, how much of that is just from the sale of the Asset Management portfolio? And I know you said you didn't want to say when the sale is going to occur, but I'm trying to figure out how dilutive that transaction, in particular, is going to be, and so we can carry that forward into the coming years.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. The Asset Management portfolio had virtually no impact on the dilution. In 2011, we earned about $0.01 or a little bit less than $0.01 from the activities from NAPICO, and it's a similar amount in 2012, as we are expecting that to be in our numbers
componenttext: Sure. The Asset Management portfolio had virtually no impact on the dilution. In 2011, we earned about $0.01 or a little bit less than $0.01 from the activities from NAPICO, and it's a similar amount in 2012, as we are expecting that to be in our numbers for most of the year. So I don't want to talk about too much about what would happen in the future other than the fact that it's only $0.01 in 2012, so it won't have a big difference. I think it's important, Eric, to point out -- you're right to point out in our numbers that you see that there's a dilution from asset sales of $0.13. But offsetting that is the reduction in expenses across the organization of $0.09. So on state, it sounds like our sell activity is quite dilutive, but we save a lot of money as we simplify the company, we take out costs, and we reduce our scale. And when you really net those 2 numbers, you can see that even with all the asset sells we've had, it hasn't been that dilutive for us on an overall basis. And going forward, we would expect something similar with the sales that we're contemplating in 2012. And the fact is we contemplate those sales, we have the opportunity to continue to save costs.

componenttext: I just wanted to ask about the delevering plans. It looked like to me the debt-to-EBITDA target number went down from when we spoke in November to today. Can you just talk about it, if that's the case, what's driving that decision to de-lever more quickly?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Karin, this is Ernie. What I'll say is we're on to different plans as we talked with folks then and we provided a presentation publicly of our NAREIT presentation for a few weeks, approximately 2 months ago. What's happening there is we're very focused on
componenttext: Karin, this is Ernie. What I'll say is we're on to different plans as we talked with folks then and we provided a presentation publicly of our NAREIT presentation for a few weeks, approximately 2 months ago. What's happening there is we're very focused on getting our coverages more in line with where our peers are, and we wanted to provide some guidance for those folks as to where that's coming in. I'll point out the numbers that I mentioned. They're both in the release and my script, and we're annualizing the fourth quarter numbers. And we did talked to folks before. We provided those annualized numbers, as well as the trailing 12 numbers and, of course, with our growth that we're going to have at EBIT throughout the year. On a trailing 12 basis, we don't get quite as far as to do it on the annualized numbers, but that's where we'll be going forward. So to derive on them, the material plans have changes. And in terms of what we wanted to deleverage of it, we want to make sure people understand that we're focused on that, and we wanted to converse that we're committed to continue to improve our coverage as we go through. I think we will recover with NOI, as well as bringing our overall debt balances down, as well as the costs of that debt term.

componenttext: No. The NAPICO was not a tax credit entity. NAPICO was a syndicator previously owned by Casden. We acquired that in a Casden transaction a decade ago, and that both institutional and retail investors certainly provided asset management services.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: If may add just to follow up there on Terry with regards to tax credit, of course, when sell some of our legacy tax credit deals that we've done under the Aimco umbrella, I just want to -- I'm cautious to use the word business. It's rather a financing opp
componenttext: If may add just to follow up there on Terry with regards to tax credit, of course, when sell some of our legacy tax credit deals that we've done under the Aimco umbrella, I just want to -- I'm cautious to use the word business. It's rather a financing opportunity. And as we talked about, we're selling a lot of our Affordable assets. And we think in the next couple of years, we'll be down to just a handful other than our legacy tax credit deals. We may choose at some point in the future to use tax credit to finance redevelopment on some of those. But in terms of trying to generate large syndication fees, et cetera, that's not the goal of that. What we're trying to accomplish or what we're looking for, cost-effective financing to do redevelopments. And there may be 1 or 2 of those we do a year, but to call it a business would be a little bit of a misnomer.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: Okay. I'm sorry, I'm getting my signals crossed in those areas, and it is there. And then a separate second question on CapEx. You kind of go through your capital restructures on redevelopment and upgrades but what can you say about recurring capital expenditures on a per-unit basis? What do you expect to spend during 2012? And how does that compare to 2011?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. We provided guidance, Rich, around what where we're doing redevelopment and property upgrades. On a recurring basis, we do expect to spend about $1,200 of capital per door, of which about $900 to $950 of that is capital replacement, and the rest of
componenttext: Sure. We provided guidance, Rich, around what where we're doing redevelopment and property upgrades. On a recurring basis, we do expect to spend about $1,200 of capital per door, of which about $900 to $950 of that is capital replacement, and the rest of that is capital improvements, where we do get a little bit of revenue uplift. And that's been consistent for the last couple of years. With times getting better and customers going to pay more rent, we have pushed for more property upgrades the last couple of years. And similar to last year, we're looking to spend about $30 million to $40 million in addition to that approximate $1,200 a door.

componenttext: I was just trying to reconcile, I think, the new leases, which you showed here as 0.7%. In October, you mentioned there was 3%, I think, over expiring leases. Just wondering what was the numbers in November and December. And then sort of how is it trending for the new year?

componenttext: Swaroop, this is Keith. I'll take that question. Swaroop, first of all, let me just reference back to my prepared remarks, particularly around that 86% of our net operating income comes from our target markets, where we had stable occupancy at 95.6% occupied, and our rents were up 1.6%, more than double the average. In our other markets, we focused on building occupancy and getting a strong jump-off point for 2012. And as we finished out January, we're on plan. And more particularly, as we look into February and March, we're starting to see early renewal rates being accepted in north of 5%.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012

componenttext: Sure, Swaroop. On the sensitivities, we're not seeing any particular sensitivities across the different A, Bs or Cs. And traffic is up, and we're feeling good about business and right on track.

componenttext: Okay. Just trying to understand better what's going on, on the new lease side. When we look at the fourth quarter this year, you had 0.7%. That's actually below what you did in 4Q '10 on new leases, although you were much stronger on renewals. And the 0.7& certainly suggests a drop-off from the October or what you've talked about last quarter. So could you just talk about new lease pricing in general? Because your guidance at least at the top end suggests that you have to get back to second or third quarter levels of increases from last year pretty quickly.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Dave, let me just say it this way. We sold for total revenue. And so while we're focused on new lease price, we're also focused on renewals and the blend of those 2, so that's how we're solving it.
componenttext: Dave, let me just say it this way. We sold for total revenue. And so while we're focused on new lease price, we're also focused on renewals and the blend of those 2, so that's how we're solving it.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: But can you talk a little bit more about the level of traffic or underlying drivers of weaker new lease pricing over the last few months as compared to October?
componenttext: But can you talk a little bit more about the level of traffic or underlying drivers of weaker new lease pricing over the last few months as compared to October?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Dave, this is Ernie. Keep in mind, we're not just solving for maximum new lease pricing or maximum renewal pricing. It's also the components with the occupancy as well. And we grew occupancy more in the fourth quarter than we would have anticipated at the
componenttext: Dave, this is Ernie. Keep in mind, we're not just solving for maximum new lease pricing or maximum renewal pricing. It's also the components with the occupancy as well. And we grew occupancy more in the fourth quarter than we would have anticipated at the beginning of the October call. We keep talking about it really is kind of a tale of the 2 portfolios for us in terms of the -- where our target market portfolio and our non-target market portfolio, and Keith has stressed that. And we didn't see that the pricing is off a little bit more than non-target markets, which makes about 40% of NOI, but we grew occupancy significantly, and that has put us in a strong position for starting 2012. Our overall basis, and I think similar to what other folks have been reporting for new lease rates and in the fourth quarter, our numbers on an aggregate basis were about where those folks were. And in fact, in our target portfolios, we're at the top end of that. That's carried over into January, where things are getting modestly better, but we haven't seen any spike in the new lease rates from where they are at today. But without providing guidance, Dave, to what's going to happen in the second, third and fourth quarters, specifically around renewal and lease rates, we do expect for the year that on a blended basis, we are going to be north of 5% on those. And as you can see from our numbers in the fourth quarter, we are there already for renewals, but it will be a lot of hard work to make sure we stay there for renewals. Let's hope that we do even better. And as you saw in our numbers during 2011, we had a pretty big spike in new lease rates as we got into the summer peak and season and then trended down, which I think was very similar to almost everyone in the industry. I'm not within the 2012 to look exactly like that, but it will be surprising if they have try to get it similar to that.

componenttext: I was curious if the disposition for next year kind of get you where you want to be in terms of your target NOI for the Affordable portion of your portfolio or whether you'll continue kind of calling that going forward?

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: Particularly with our disposition guidance, it gets us closer. We're going to get to -- eventually, to a point where it's less than 10% of our NOI and NAV, and we're getting close to that but not quite there in 2012. I expect there'd be -- if we don't get
componenttext: Particularly with our disposition guidance, it gets us closer. We're going to get to -- eventually, to a point where it's less than 10% of our NOI and NAV, and we're getting close to that but not quite there in 2012. I expect there'd be -- if we don't get it done in 2012, another maybe 20 to 25 more properties to sell as we go into 2013. So what I'll tell you is we're almost there. As we sell these properties, it doesn't make a big change in the contribution because these are our Affordable properties with low ownership percentage across our portfolio. And then longer term, we continue to expect the quarter, it will become a smaller and smaller contributor to our -- the overall income picture in terms of NAV, as well as NOI. So we would talk about wanting to be at 10% or a little bit less, and we're going to be almost there with what we plan to do in 2012.

headline: Apartment Investment & Management Co., Q4 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 08, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then I guess a kind of bigger picture, given the kind of current platform you have, what do you think is the appropriate size for the company?
componenttext: And then I guess a kind of bigger picture, given the kind of current platform you have, what do you think is the appropriate size for the company?

componenttextpreview: Jana, it's Terry. I think we're roughly $10 billion. That's a comfortable size. We've been larger at other times. It'd be okay if we were a little bit larger. We've been smaller, and that would be okay, too. It's the size where transactions and improved p
componenttext: Jana, it's Terry. I think we're roughly $10 billion. That's a comfortable size. We've been larger at other times. It'd be okay if we were a little bit larger. We've been smaller, and that would be okay, too. It's the size where transactions and improved performance can move the dial, and so I like this size, about where it is.
